A wide range of philosophical moral traditions exist; religious moral traditions exist next to secular moral frameworks such as [[humanism]], [[utilitarianism]], and others. There are many types of religious morals. The [[monotheistic]] religions, such as [[Islam]], [[Judaism]], [[Christianity]], and to a certain degree others such as [[Sikhism]], define right and wrong by the laws and rules set forth by their respective gods and as interpreted by religious figures within the respective faith. [[Polytheistic]] religious traditions tend to diverge from this path. For example, within Buddhism, the intention of the individual and the circumstances should be accounted for to determine if an action is right or wrong.<ref> Peggy Morgan, "Buddhism," in {{cite book |title= Ethical Issues in Six Religious Traditions |edition= Second|last1= Lawton|first1= Clive|authorlink1= |last2= Morgan|first2= Peggy |year= 2007|publisher= Columbia University Press|location= |isbn= 978-0748623303 |pages= 61, 88–89}}</ref> The varying moral frameworks of religions provide different ways of dealing with oral dilemmas. For example, there is no absolute prohibition on killing in Hinduism, and Hinduism recognizes that killing "may be inevitable and indeed necessary" in certain circumstances.<ref>Werner Menski, "Hinduism." In {{cite book |title= Ethical Issues in Six Religious Traditions |edition= Second|last1= Lawton|first1= Clive|authorlink1= |last2= Morgan|first2= Peggy |year= 2007|publisher= Columbia University Press|location= |isbn= 978-0748623303 |page= 5}}</ref>
